source.2e3e3750:
#The way in which the winners and losers of football are ranked.

Marcelo Bielsa has already been stereotyped as romantic, visionary, defeated ... He was marked by the Argentine fall in the first phase of the 2002 World Cup, he left his post after the Olympic gold medal in Athens, he left his football seal and the adoration of many people in Bilbao, Marseille or Chile. The memories are as great a recognition as the cups, but the result screams. And whenever he referred to the way in which the winners and losers of football are ranked, Bielsa did it with a unique dignity: “Here is someone speaking who knew failure well”.

At this point, for Bielsa, football imitates life, as he warned young people in an Argentine school: “Do not allow failure to damage your self-esteem. There is a tendency to offend you just because you lost. 

#When you win, they flatter you without examining why you won, what resources you used ”.

source.0ebf91d9:
#Pride and adaptation

This adaptability is a quality of Ferguson, but not so with most technicians. They come into the game with a big idea that is influential and defines them - and they stick to it. That may be why Sacchi lasted only seven years at the top, and Johan Cruyff, eight. Its peaks really could be higher, because the nature of its ideology brought a more intense level of application, but this ideology depends on being at the right moment.

It is true that there is a period when the technicians have a greater energy, a fierce hunger before the conquests start to satisfy them.

Football figures say they have recognized similarities between Mourinho, Wenger and Rafa Benítez. It is not so much about ideology as it is about pride. They are not as attached to tactics as to the idea of ​​proving that they are right, that what they do can still work.

It is not yet known whether Klopp and Guardiola will succumb to the same problem. What is true, however, is that both have already adapted to each other's ideas.https://translate.googleusercontent.com/translate_c?depth=1&hl=en&prev=search&pto=aue&rurl=translate.google.com.br&sl=pt&sp=nmt4&u=https://oglobo.globo.com/esportes/quando-um-tecnico-de-futebol-esta-ultrapassado-1-24525652&usg=ALkJrhi1OLUrRojy7tGPiOjAQKf1btndXw
source.69d055ff:
#The kind of success that the statistic ignores

Two years ago, Bielsa took over the traditional Leeds United, then underrated to move up to the Premier League. He built a team in his own way, offensive, showy, generous with football. In the first season, he hit the post like so many times in his career. On Saturday, he became champion of the English second division. Leeds returned to the elite after 16 years, the same time Bielsa had to wait to find what they call success.

All this time, he played football in his own way, delighted, aroused good feelings in people, inspired the best coaches in the world. Football cannot do without people like that. It is the kind of success that the statistic ignores.

https://translate.google.com.br/translate?hl=en&sl=pt&u=https://oglobo.globo.com/esportes/percurso-de-bielsa-mostra-que-ha-muitas-formas-de-ser-influente-no-futebol-nao-apenas-com-titulos-1-24541270&prev=search&pto=aue

source.44b27c00:
#Ideas are not eternal

The history of European football can be told through his great coaches: Nereo Rocco popularized the catenaccio defensive model by winning the Champions League with Milan (1962/1963), before Jock Stein ran over with Celtic. Rinus Michels' Ajax took the game to a whole new level with “total football”. Opponents could not handle the pressure, which was a revolutionary idea.

As other coaches adapted, they discovered solutions that led to further changes. Pressure was not so used in the 1980s, until the Italian Arrigo Sacchi improved it in his time, before Guardiola did the same.

All of this is further influenced by developments in sports science and psychology, which coaches need to be up to date on.

This is crucial: a good idea is not a good idea forever. What worked so well for 10, 15 years may not work now. The context may have changed. https://translate.googleusercontent.com/translate_c?depth=1&hl=en&prev=search&pto=aue&rurl=translate.google.com.br&sl=pt&sp=nmt4&u=https://oglobo.globo.com/esportes/quando-um-tecnico-de-futebol-esta-ultrapassado-1-24525652&usg=ALkJrhi1OLUrRojy7tGPiOjAQKf1btndXw
source.6571cd27:
#When is a football coach overtaken?

Last year, the board of a major European club was discussing the next coach and an important name was suggested. He was quickly dismissed: "It's out of date", were the words of an influential director. It is a common comment in football, and even some coaches have used it to define each other. They say that life goes fast, but not as fast as football. This is the point.

The way football leaves coaches behind is difficult to explain, but it is real. That is how someone like Giovanni Trapattoni, champion of the Champions League for Juventus (1985), can end up training Ireland; that José Mourinho ended up at Tottenham; and Carlo Ancelotti, at Everton. Suddenly, the coaches discover that they are not being sought out by the best clubs, because they are not winning the trophies of the same level, falling into a gradual fall.

#Rise, Peak and Decline

It is from these great titles that it is possible to calculate how long a coach can follow at the top with great jobs. According to a survey by the Independent, from England, the average is 12.3 years. It was arrived at from the history of 50 coaches, with different profiles. They fit the logic that careers tend to last about 30 years and usually go through three stages: rise, peak and decline.

This peak is the time between the first and the last great success of a coach. Great success in lifting is a national league title or reaching the Champions League final. In the case of team work, winning the Euro or reaching the decision of a World Cup.

This is not to say that those that are on top 10 will start to worry in the next two years. It is not a matter of fighting an “imaginary clock”, but of following the tangible changes of the game. Coaches themselves dictate this pace. The best are very intelligent, full of ideas that defy orthodox models.

https://translate.googleusercontent.com/translate_c?depth=1&hl=en&prev=search&pto=aue&rurl=translate.google.com.br&sl=pt&sp=nmt4&u=https://oglobo.globo.com/esportes/quando-um-tecnico-de-futebol-esta-ultrapassado-1-24525652&usg=ALkJrhi1OLUrRojy7tGPiOjAQKf1btndXw
source.1252072e:
#Finding what they call success.

Bielsa's (Marcelo Bielsa) path shows that there are many ways to be influential in football, not just with titles.

Coach puts Leeds back in the English elite after 16 years, the same time he had to wait to find what they call success.

It is pertinent to discuss the capacity of each coach to adapt, to adapt his ideas to new questions that the game is proposing. But the method fails to be mathematical and resultant. Had Barcelona taken advantage of one of the many counterattacks at Anfield and avoided Liverpool's unlikely turnaround in 2019, Klopp would have stretched his long hiatus without cups. It does not seem reasonable that a Messi kick or a point in the race against Manchester City last season would exclude him from the elite.

#A distortion of the sense of success (Adulation of the victors regardless of the legacies).

The method has merits, but it ends up reinforcing a distortion of the sense of success, an adulation of the victors regardless of the legacies. Titles can age, ideas cannot. And, driven by them, a coach can contribute to football in many ways: as a thinker, as inspiration for those who end up consecrating themselves with results, or for the defense of a football played with values and dignity.

Mere statistics exclude, for example, Marcelo Bielsa, whose path has each of these virtues: “In any job you can win or lose. The important thing is the nobility of the resources used ", he says.

Guardiola has already called him “the best coach in the world” for his contributions to the game with ideas, or for his ability to improve his athletes. But the method used by the English article overestimates much of what Bielsa has always condemned in the way he thinks of football characters.
